page.title: 07The Canal At Tring
page.content: The first survey of the route for a new canal was undertaken by James Barnes and it was resurveyed by William Jessop in 1772.By December 1773 3,000 men were at work.The canal could take barges carrying 70tons.The lock dimensions allowed a pair of narrow boats to go through at once.The most difficult engineering was crossing the high ground at the summit near Tring. At Tring a cutting was made through the Chiltern Hills one and a half miles long and 30feet deep.It was completed in 1797 also Wendover Arm which fed water to the summit.The stretch from the summit south of Berkhamsted was opened in 1799,and the stretch north of Fenny Stratford was opened in May 1800.Nowadays the canal is used by boatmen,fishermen and for walks along the towpaths.
